title: He's All That
summary: A teenage girl sets out to give a nebbish classmate the ultimate high school makeover. An updated remake of the 1999 film, 'She's All That'.

reviews.review_title: THE ONLY GOOD ACTING IN THIS MOVIE WAS FROM THE HORSE!!!!!
reviews.content: What was this movie? Didn't even make sense one bit. Terrible acting from Addison. The scene transitions, the angles, the story line, the gen Z infested bs & the random dance off lmao.. it was a hot mess!!! I was looking forward to this all week and it was a big let down. DO NOT WATCH.

reviews.review_title: The 'loser' was hot even before the makeover
reviews.content: What a cringeworthy remake.The original does not age well, and whilst this remake is a fun idea, overall it fails.Taking off his beanie and getting a haircut isn't exactly a makeover and besides, he's super hot already. Are we meant to believe that wearing a beanie and having long hair makes you a loser? HIS HAIR WAS BEAUTIFUL!And why on earth is Kourtney Kardashian in it? So random.

Matthew Lillard was better in the 10 minutes he was around then all the other "teens" through the rest of the movie.I went into this with low expectations and was still disappointed. It was good if you wanted a braindead watch but the ending with the horse.... god so cringe.The writing and acting were horrendous. The two original actors carried every scene they were in with the exception of the little sister.

reviews.review_title: Holy crap this is soooo bad
reviews.content: And who the hell is Addison Rae? Somebody told her she could act...and forgot to add JK.

This movie is an insult to 'She's All That'.The movie is so bad that it's ridiculous to even call it a 'movie'.It's ironic that the actors and actresses in the movie represent in their real lives everything the movie criticizes.I have to watch the 'She's All That' DVD this weekend.

Words cannot describe how bad this film is. It shows you how awful movies are made now. The acting is down right awful but the leads are not really actors there tik tok stars. Overall it's a long tik tok commercial. Stick with the original.

Holy cow this movie is terrible.Between being rushed, terrible dialogue, and no chemistry between the characters.. Product placement and the couple big names in the movie are the only way this thing was made. Its basically a parody of She's All That. When will society learn that not everyone that gets famous on social media has actual talent?

This movie is so bad. TBH, it doesn't even feel like a movie, it's just like some type of a vlog or school project. The acting, especially Addison Rae's, is terrible. Everything else - extremely cringe and awkward. Zero chemistry, weird camera angles... Just watch anything else instead.

As an adult I should not have watched this movie, to a young person it might have been tolerable and relevant. However, in my opinion it was painful. The acting was stiff and the actors had no chemistry. The storyline was expected, but some really laughable moments - prom dance off? Is that even a thing?

Awful main female lead acting and even more so, Awful modern teen culture. Main male lead is prettier than main female lead.This movie feels forced. Everything is off.Main lead is unattractive and can't act. At all. I think Paris Hilton was a better actress. The guy looks better even in his "antisocial" condition than her in her "hot" condition.There is a forced same sex love story that they put into the mix, but I guess it's just rolling with the "woke" times.Do yourself a favor and watch the original. Much better.Another flop by Netflix.
Apparently everyone can act, honestly start looking for talented actors instead of looking for TikTokers.

reviews.review_title: Out of respect for Cook and Lilliard... please avoid if you have enough of cell cams
reviews.content: Though was pleased to see Rachael Leigh Cook (as a mom) and Matthew Lilliard (as a principal), the latters from the original "She's all That!" which I will always enjoy, unfortunately, seeing too much exposure from a teen girl from her cell phone to get popularity, until she makes this infamous bet to transform this stable boy into a cool guy, well, not my genre.Stick with the original, at least a rich guy gets out of his snooty entourage and get some life...(should have given one star, but seeing some nostalgia from Rachael and Matthew, as well as the red dress and the song Kiss Me in a different interpretation, boosted 2 more stars but that's how it goes...)

Rom com? Nope. The social media angle was a good idea but she tells everyone how 'fake' it all is at the end while she purposely films it for... social media.Guess it was never really going to point out how evil social media is with Addison Rae in the lead. (She was ok as an actress)And that dance off at the end? 😂😂😂(Rachael Leigh cook looks a million bucks though!)
I cringed so hard that my soul climbed out of my body and now I'm doomed to roam the earth as a ghost, cringing for all eternity.

Just bc you have millions of followers on tik tok doesn't mean you actually have talent. This movie shouldn't have been remade anyway but since it was, there are far better candidates for the job long before her. Pathetic.

Oh goodness this was a painful watch. Where did these actors get their acting lessons out of a cereal box?..the best acting in this whole movie was Matthew Lillard and he was on for about 5min..Like some have said this was a major cringe movie. I cringed so hard my eyes went all wonky...terrible Netflix just terrible.
Why are they making tiktokers famous? Ruining everything for us.

Wow, what a load of rubbish. I thought it would be a standard funny, cheesy, high school flick but it was a waste of time. Even my 10 year old got bored and said how rubbish it was. How this got made is unbelievable. What was with the dance off scene 😂😂😂 I absolutely cringed.
Bad dialogue, unrealistic reactions, cringe all the way, way too much product placements. Was this written and directed by a teenager?
Completely terrible from beginning to end. In every way possible.

reviews.review_title: It's all about Tik Tok meets Can't Buy Me Love on this 2021 remake of an underrated teen flick
reviews.content: He's All That is a gender blended romantic teen comedy directed by Mark Waters(Just Like Heaven,Mean Girls)and stars Addison Rae(in her movie debut as she is famous for Tik Tok),Tanner Buchanan,Rachel Leigh Cook,Matthew Lillard and Madison Pettis.Almost a shot for shot of the 1999 version this one centres on a popular girl named Padgett Sawyer(Addison Rae) who just got dumped by her boyfriend after she caught him cheating on her with another woman. Heartbroken she gets her own back at him with help from her friend Aiden(Madison Pettis) by making a bet that she can transform any nerdy guy into a prom king. She decides to place her bet on an antisocial photographer named Cameron Kweller(Tanner Buchanan) who isn't all that popular. At first she is enjoying her little bet,but she later finds herself falling for Cameron (after he got a makeover).Will Cameron and Padgett end up being together in the end?. Well you betcha they do.Overall I thought it was OK. The original one was way better in my opinion as this seems like a product placement for Tik Tok.Also stars 2 of the original She's All That actors as different characters Rachel Leigh Cook as Addison's mom(she was the nerdy girl in the original one) and Matthew Lillard as Principal Bosch(who played the douchbag Freddie Prinze Jr's ex girlfriend dated). And a surprise cameo by Kourntey Kardashian as Jessica.Shame Freddie Prinze Jr didn't make a cameo.
The whole movie all I could see was sponsors. The water, pop corn, chips, drinks.... You name it. The movie sucked I thought it would be way more fun and I found myself not impressed at all.
The reviews are more entertaining than the movie. That's my review.

reviews.review_title: Sorry, I couldn't even stomach enough of it to give a good review
reviews.content: I personally could not even stomach more than maybe 10 mins of this to even give an in-depth review on what I saw. What I did see was weird camera angles, camcorder like saturation, over the top stereotype to the point of being uncanny and unrealistic, and an over saturation of Gen-Z Rebecca Black "Friday" type Preppy style that I could not swallow. Instead of watching a character that was that lifestyle, it felt more like an unnatural interpretation attempt at being Polly Pocket.I hope Netflix knows what this is or I am completely wrong and there is a demographic out there that I will never understand that will like stuff like this. Because this can't be good for business.

reviews.review_title: "High school is just a bunch of scared people pretending to be something they're not"
reviews.content: This might be like, the first 'new' Miramax, ew, movie i've seen. Why do #social media influencers never sleep with their phone on charge. Why? You can get contactless docs now. AnywayZ, da acting was Vom, and the storyline was like so last century. This was defs no Gossip Girl, XoXo, don't call me. Ever.

reviews.review_title: 0 out of 10 bad movie, bad acting, don't waste your time. The metascore 3.4 by real critics and bad reviews/ratings by us who watched it says it all!
reviews.content: 0 out of 10 bad movie, bad acting, don't waste your time, the lead actress can't act either.Spend your time either watching: Promising Young Woman (2020) or Young Royals (2021). Highly recommend, these two are a good watch, with substance and a message, with this you'll watch something to learn from and something to think about.
Terrible acting and the whole social media reality show feel bs makes it worse. She's all that wasn't a good movie but compared to this it's Oscar worthy.

First let me say, I had no idea who the lead was. Five minutes into the movie I was beyond frustrated; who is this female lead and why do her acting skills remind me of a local waitress auditioning for a milk ad in the 1960s? Then I looked the cast and boom, it all made sense. I should've expected nothing less. This movie had all the aspects of an unrealistic, poorly written, amateurish, predictable, high budget but with untalented casting staff movie. What's the point of saturating a movie with famous actors for views? Unfortunately I'm unable to regain the hour and half I wasted clenching my jaws, awkwardly glancing at my imaginary friends around the room as I react to every minute that passes of this movie. If I could give zero stars this movie would be a suitable place to start. Tell a friend to tell a friend, save them the future dental work....(teeth grinding)

If you think that Instagram influencers and TikTok is the meaning of life, then these atrocious actors will have some mediocre appeal. It made me reevaluate if I ever even liked the first rendition. It's crap.
The people are pretty, and sets are beautiful, but the story is vacant and empty. I don't relate to the vain superficiality at all.

reviews.review_title: An advert for TikTok - Rarely do I get angered by a movie
reviews.content: What in the hell did I just watch? What a disaster of a movie in every way possible. Rarely do I get angered by a movie but this was just disgusting in every possible way.I loved the original, it had good actors, had real heart, and tasteful music in appropriate places.This is just one huge tiktok advert with product placements all over the place, KFC/Pizza hut, you name it it's here. We know who sponsored this movie and the production. Anyone watching this, they are making money off you. Believe me, it is not worth watching at all.The acting is just so bad, the script, camera angles are horrendous, the dialogue is cringe and awkward. "IPhone, followers,, tiktok, pizza hut, some more tiktok followed by some random fruity loops " is all this disaster of a movie is. The director and actors and everyone involved should be ashamed of themselves for not speaking up during shooting that this was going to be a disaster and walking away.HORRIBLE.

It's an insult for every person ever worked on any movie. Disgusting. Is there one single person on this planet who actually thinks this.....thing (I refuse to call this movie)......is GOOD????Worst thing I have seen (even a lot worse than Fifty Shades of Grey or 365 days).I'm disgusted and sad.

reviews.review_title: The REAL Movie Stars had to step in and promote this for the kiddos.
reviews.content: It's a cute little movie to watch. There's a lot of things they did wrong and I feel bad for the actor that plays Cameron who had to try and force chemistry with a lead who has no clue what's she's doing and to have to carry the movie. The scene that displayed acting like I have never ever seen in my life is after the Cameron makeover & before the reveal. Literally the lead "actress"/not an actress must of read the script's notes: "Cameron enters room and his handsome face takes Padge's breath away." In that scene she is literally panting when she see Cameron's newfound hotness. To be fair, my pug pants real hard like that when I come out of the bathroom too. I thought maybe I missed a scene where she was doing aerobics for a bit before he came out of the bathroom but no, that's just how she played it.. Interesting interpretation I guess.Then a Kardashian shows up. Doesn't even matter which one, they are all the literal worst.Like, why Netflix? Why do you hate us?Rachael Leigh Cook and the 2 minutes of Matthew Lillard was Netflix's apology to the viewer's for the rest of the film.I could watch those two in anything.They really should of just done a geriatric remake and brought back Freddy and they could of just read lines from the original movie. I'd be in for that.Also, laughing at the reviews that say she did a good job because it's her first movie....literally.... PANTING!!!4 Stars because Rachael, Matthew, Tanner and the horse.

reviews.review_title: If only I could give this film a 0/10
reviews.content: Addison Rae is a terrible actress, I'm sorry I can't sugarcoat that. They're plenty of other immensely talented actresses that they could've hired but they went with Addison due to her Tiktok fame (and obviously having her in the film means more views). This film wasn't worth the time I spent on it, and the only thing that made up for it was Rachael Leigh.

reviews.review_title: Can we get a good heartwarming movie

Unfortunately, I was hoping it would be a remake
of the original. But the acting was awful accept for Tanner. They just don't make teen movies like they used to make :-(

reviews.review_title: Not everyone can act and produce a good movie 😬
reviews.content: Dont waste your time. It wasnt good netflix should have thought this through and should have had common sense before releasing this their target audience had to have been gen z but none of us even liked it cuz of the casting no offence.

reviews.review_title: A shameless mockery of a classic teen rom-com
reviews.content: Everything for the eyes of a pretty rich girl. This is pretty much what I think when I saw this movie. There is so many talented artists out there, but for the remake of She's All That, executives has chosen privilege over artistic awareness. And by casting Ms. Addison Rae as their lead, they have sent a message: "If you a rich and pretty, you will be given priority over other poorer artists." This isn't new but this is also very sad. And that kind of choices have consequences.Here, we are talking about a dull remake with very questionable acting skills from the main actress. The thing with bad acting is this. Watching an actor embracing a character should give to the viewers an immersive experience: We forget that we are watching a character and we start to believe that we are watching real life people being filmed. When a bad actor tries himself in the production a movie, that immersive experience is ruined and instead, we realize that we are watching an actor painfully reading his/her lines. And this is exactly what one will experience by watching Ms. Rae on He's All That. You are not watching a character, you are watching someone 'trying' to be an actor in an average budget movie. And I hate to say that about a (wannabe/would be)actress, but the all thing smell 'fraud'.The silver lining is that the other professional actors did very well (and the difference is noticeable in every scenes) except from a cameo from a famous reality show contestant, that I won't spoil for you here if you are still interested in watching the movie. And it's always a pleasure to see Rachael Leigh Cook on screen, even though she looks way to young to be playing this lady's mother.The story is very typical and you couldn't do more cliché. But usually, with that type of predictable movie, there is always an element of charm to them. You know how it will end, but you appreciate the ride. We sadly do not get that here, apart from a few moments with Tanner Buchanan and especially Isabella Crovetti (the best actor here). The all thing seems a bit un-naturally manufactured, as if an AI had generated a movie by mixing and using all the elements that have been done in every teen rom-coms before it. The movie is also too fancy and clean whereas the original was a bit gritty in a few aspects. The humor also fall flat.I would have loved a good gender swap remake of She's All That as the concept wasn't a bad idea in itself. But I just wish Hollywood would drop the habit of privileging non-talented people to please the rich and beautiful who suddenly feel like they are actors, because they have money in their bank accounts (and because they said so), instead of choosing quality and talent. How many times have we seen privileged people steal the place of poorer better talents? A habit that I wish we would leave behind in 2021. I don't know much about her talents as a dancer though, and maybe she's very good at that, but Addison Rae simply isn't an actress.I am putting a 2/10 for Isabella Crovetti, but there is not much else here.

Can you smell what Rachel is cooking? Name puns aside, it was nice to see her again. And if I may say she has aged beautiful. Doesn't seem to have had any work done on her - which I'm glad she didn't. But it is not her movie - it was her movie in the 90s when it was about her in "She's all that".Now I don't remember much of it, but I reckon it was silly and light fun. Just as this is. This is not awards season fodder. This is also not meant to excite any acting or story driven fans. I would expect that people who are looking forward to see this, would be aware of this. If you weren't I hope you are now.Does this have flaws and does the ugly duckling story have issues all over the place? Yes but the charisma of the actors involved may make that obsolete. Or at least make it dissapear to a degree. Predictable, but I have seen worse.

reviews.review_title: Bad acting, bad production, poor filmography
reviews.content: See title. A complete waste of an hour and a half.

reviews.review_title: First One is a Masterpiece Compared to This Drivel
reviews.content: This version makes the first one seem like a masterpiece, which was on the shallow end of teen romcoms. If this is a foreshadow of what acting will be, I'm gonna stop watching movies all together because may as well watch YouTube. And did they really need to include a Kardashian play a character, not even themself, in order to attract an audience? Pathetic. I really wanted to enjoy this update and was sadly exceedingly disappointed. Good production values makes it a 2.

Had low expectations but still disappointed with Mark Waters' gender-swaps remake. It tried to modernize everything into these whole 'gen Z' situations. Rae & Buchanan only got few decent moments to share their honest thoughts and awkward chemistry together.Watch it for Leigh Cook & Lillard's cameo here.

reviews.review_title: A 2021 Movie where a dance off to Macklemore's Dance Off happens.
reviews.content:
The Good: Look, the worst movies are mediocre ones. Ones where they go into your eyes and out your brain almost immediately after you see them. Netflix has a lot of those. This is not one of them.The Bad: This may legitimately be a list of every aspect of film and filmmaking. I'm not joking. This movie is competently made; it's a movie with a plot that goes from A to B, it conveys information adequately and it looks (kinda) like a movie. Aside from that baseline, pretty much everything - the acting, writing, editing, cinematography, costumes, set design, dialog - is absolutely awful. I'll mention two things: Addison Rae is REALLY trying here, but for most of the movie she sounds like she's pitching an ad, not speaking to actual people. To be fair, most of the actors here are REALLY, REALLY bad. The other thing I'll note is how poorly the writers understand youth, and particularly,
internet, culture. Why would you even make this movie, if not to take the original story, but modify it for a new audience? They think they're doing it, but there's no explanation or representation for how this generation is different from the kids of the original. To me, that's such a missed opportunity.The Ugly: This movie is so insanely stuffed with brands, I almost couldn't believe it. Then I realized that maybe, just maybe, it was an inadvertent reflection of how seemingly half of all kids nowadays are intent in building a future via sponsorship by large corporations. Oh and Courtney Kardashian is in this. She's terrible. TRULY.

By far one of the worst constructed movies I've seen in 2021. The acting was horrendously terrible it seemed as if there were no real actors and it was this little forced gimmick trying to be pushed off as a romcom. In conclusion easily one of the worst movies of this year but didn't really expect anything from it going into it.

reviews.review_title: It's too late for me, save yourselves
reviews.content: I am too ancient it seems to know who Addison Lee is but she's no Freddie PJ. This lack of context meant I thought the bizarre hyper unrealism of her acting was going to be revealed as a plot point. What a grave misconception to imagine this film had anything like so much substance. I won't spoil anything in case anyone is mad enough to be reading these reviews and still watch, but I am about to take a long hard look in the mirror for making it through this film without throwing up.Oddly however this did pass the Kermode six laugh test for me, a one liner from an underused elderly relative woke me up and laughter of at least five times the duration emerged during the denouement. Not sure if that counts actually, please don't bother. As for the preposterous physique of the "loser" leading man and patronising nods towards diversity I have no words. Oh a kardashian pops up.

reviews.review_title: 1hr and 30mins of a tiktoker trying to act. 1hr and 30mins I'm never getting back.
reviews.content:
Lmao... Addison. You can't act. This was a fun experiment, never do it again. Your acting is absolutely horrendous and extremely monotone. You sound like a robot. Gosh. You can't sing. I had to turn my volume down when you started singing in the movie. Please stick to moving your arms around on TikTok. Just because you lip sync on an app, doesn't mean you can act. Next thing you know, Addison Rae's going to be an astronaut.This is the worst film on Netflix. So cringy. Whoever wrote the script HAS to be a middle schooler. Nobody, and I mean NOBODY, can act. When I say NOBODY, I really do just mean Addison. Also, this is the most random cast I've ever seen. Why is KOURTNEY KARDASHIAN in this?Random commentary as I forced myself to watch this monstrosity:
Am I hearing correctly, or did that girl just call her brother hot?After all he did was get a haircut and clean up his face a little, all of a sudden he's hot? Lmao.Did he just say ''BS'' in a conversation, like out loud?What's up with the random dance off?...
She didn't even know if she was going to win or not. How does she have a whole slideshow?The horse.... CRINGE FEST!PLEASE PLEASE watch ANYTHING else. Save yourself.. I only watched this to see how bad it would be.

reviews.review_title: I wasn't expecting much from this but my god..
reviews.content: This is the biggest load of garbage I have ever had to sit through in my life no exaggeration and I'm 21 years old.I'm not even sure where to start I got reeled into to watching this by my little cousin who is obsessed with Addison Rae for a bizarre reason I cannot understand. I had very low expectations going into this film but shockingly it was even worse than I'd thought it'd beIf this is our generations version of a romcom then we are screwed.. what happened to classics like sleepless in Seattle or. Bridget Jones diary ETC.Can we not just have a heartwarming romcom anymore? Instead we are stuck with this garbage.. I am worried for the future of film.

I feel like the producers didn't do a good job on the green screen when Addison was singing if you look closely you see she's dancing behind a green screen. Overall the acting wasn't that great and I just hoped that it would be a remake.

This is the worse reboot and romcom movie ever, addison CAN'T ACT AT ALL, she's not natural and everything is forced, not to mention the cringy tiktok dances and the singing is awful. Madison should've been the lead actress and addison shouldve had a cameo as her debut acting??

reviews.review_title: Not All That! Everything is the Same, but MUCH WORSE
reviews.content: Yeah, it's suppossed to be a remake, sequel, re-quel? Of a good 90's teen romance comedy movie.This is not as good, not as entertaining, the music sucks, the acting is awful and the plot while the same, but worse.It's terrible. They actually bought 2-3 characters from the original, but it's bad. There is now a gay girl bc reasons, and did I mentioned everything is the same but worse?Guy is a "geek," now that I think about it, it's more like a mash between 'She;s All That,' and 'Drive Me Crazy,' at least the main character is.I am done, I can't any more, it was bad all around. While the original 'SHE's All That' was made for older teens and young adults, 'He's NOT All That' feeling like it was made for Disney Teens and kids who have no idea what makes a good movie.It's Awful, 2 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: TikTok celebrities are NOT good actors
reviews.content: The actors in this movie aren't considered actors. The idea of remaking a movie is great, but it's how you make it. The gen Z setting is really disgusting and cringe. It's all about "Followers" & who has the bigger D. It's all white trash, which is what a huge turn-off. The only good actor, well, amazing actor is Tanner Buchanan. Good movie idea, bad acting and setting.
This was hands down the worst movie I ever watched.

reviews.review_title: A good way to remove a few extra brain cells
reviews.content: I gained too much knowledge from my Physics lecture that I was stressed and always had headaches. However when I watched this movie I slowly felt my IQ oozing out of my brain as my brain neurons begged for help, I now live in a cave den in Southwestern Ethiopia and has to forage rocks and discarded animals corpses to survive.

Acting in this movie is atrocious. Seems like even the actors were trying to get done as quick as possible, rushing through scenes realizing that this movie was just the same as thousands of other teen romance movies. Same plot with nothing new. Will probably appeal to the segment of millennials who have never seen a movie but probably no one else. Would have been one star instead of two but I have seen the actors in other roles so I know it wasn't their fault, just the script. Will look for them in better future roles.

I was a huge fan of the original movie. This movie was cringeworthy. The script was horrible and the actors unfortunately were not believable. What hurt the most was diminishing the character, Laney Bogs, from the original to a bitter workaholic single mom. The original didn't need a remake and we see why. If I could give 0/10, I would have. A waste of 1 hour and 31 mins I'll never get back.
My brain can only handle so much, I was genuinely in pain during my time watching this movie. Do not watch it.

reviews.review_title: Shaking Your A_ _ on Tik Tok Doesn't Mean She Can Act!
reviews.content: I could t get past the first 30 Mins! Addison Rae CANNOT ACT! She's Terrible. I'm sorry but just because tweens fawn over her shaking her A_ _ ( it's the same dance everytime) on Tik Tok doesn't mean you give her a movie. She's needs to find out real fast that the rest of the world doesn't give two cents about Tik Tok "celebrities". SMH... Seriously!

With a clichéd story this movie is bad, but it does have a few things to highlight.Although it develops a very predictable storyline, it manages to be attractive in the first half of the film, but as it progresses, it becomes tired and desperate. The remarkable things are the message you want to give about social networks and the falsehood that is in them, the good performance of Isabella Crovetti, how entertaining it can be at first, that shows the superficiality of people by pretending something they are not. There are many script holes, there is no chemistry between the protagonists, there is no explanation of why things happen, there are scenes that do not contribute anything to the story, just as there are characters that do not contribute much to the plot.The message can be contradicted at the end of the film and the main female character does not have a personal growth, which the male character does have but is more inclined towards his growth than how he shows himself to the world. reviews.content: So cringe I couldn't even finish the movie. Terrible acting.... I can see how teens would like it, but the only good thing about this movie is Racheal Leigh Cook making an appearance. Go watch She's All That instead.

reviews.review_title: A soulless cringe-fest created for rich white influencers
reviews.content: Auditions exist for a reason. We all know of them -- they're the process where the creators of a movie check to see if an actor actually has talent before casting them in a role. This is exactly what the creators of HE'S ALL THAT, a new Netflix high school rom-com, should have done before casting TikTok influencer Addison Rae in the lead role of their film. To be fair, Rae's casting in this film is the least of its problems, but it is still confounding that such a popular movie has such an uncharismatic and bland lead performance anchoring the story. With that being said, HE'S ALL THAT is a failure in almost every possible way. If a person above the age of 50 viewed this movie without any context, they would want to purge the entirety of Gen Z from the Earth after viewing. Not only is it awkward, cringe-worthy and painfully predictable, but it promotes a privileged, rich and LA-centric version of life that I wish would only be documented in a negative connotation.The film is a remake of the 1999 rom-com She's All That, except this film is gender-swapped and centers around a social-media influencer. Essentially, Padgett Sawyer (Addison Rae playing herself) must regain her social media fame when an embarrassing incident causes her to lose followers. In order to do this, she places a bet with her friend that she can make the biggest loser in the school to win prom king with her. After she chooses Cameron Kweller (Tanner Buchanan), an old-fashioned guy with no social media presence who likes Bad Religion and Kubrick, thus begins a romance that everyone has seen a million times before except far better. I understand that rom-coms like this aren't supposed to be judged based on their predictability, but when during any point in the movie I found myself being able to predict beat-for-beat how the next few scenes would play out, I'd say there's a problem.The only things that weren't contributing to the mediocrity in this movie are Tanner Buchanan, Rachael Leigh Cook and Matthew Lillard. The latter two are only present because they were in the original 1999 film, so it's only natural they're far better than the rest of the cast. Tanner Buchanan attempts to pull his own weight here (he was very good in Cobra Kai, the Karate Kid sequel show), but neither him nor anyone else can really do anything with the atrocious material they are given to work with. The dialogue here sounds like the wealthy L. A. screenwriter wrote it half asleep without knowing anything about public schooling and sent it to production without proofreading it. On top of that, the acting, for the most part, seems like a middle school play where the students are reading their lines straight from a piece of paper. The scenes near the end where characters have to get emotional are so badly acted that I laughed about ten times more than when the movie was actually trying to make me laugh.What bothers me about many high school movies that get greenlit recently is the focus on rich, white and affluent neighborhoods and an ignorance of the high school stories that are actually interesting. HE'S ALL THAT is that trend on steroids, to the point where the message of the movie involving influencers on social media is only relatable to those who have the time and money to indulge in this culture. The film seems like it was made for and by rich white people in Los Angeles, and seems to be a symptom of people like Addison Rae being able to do literally whatever they want with no consequences. The ultimate irony of HE'S ALL THAT is the fact that the message involves how influencers are more interesting and personable than the fake pictures they post online, yet this film is the most soulless and fake product from Netflix all year. Way to prove the haters right.HE'S ALL THAT is worth watching if you and friends want something to ruthlessly roast while eating snacks or doing something else that will require more of your attention. Other than that, I'd say this film is one to avoid unless you enjoy cringing for an hour and thirty minutes straight. Supposedly Addison Rae has a deal with Netflix to executive produce and star in at least three more projects, which sounds like the worst idea since producing a live-action version of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Cats. Giving this movie money by watching it is the cinematic equivalent of driving an SUV and contributing to the destruction of the environment. For the love of God, buy an electric car instead.D-

No saving grace for this movie. It's honestly super offensive that we are only hiring people because they are famous. Addison is a terrible actress and that's just the hard truth coming from a movie reviewer. This is what I would like to call "fake acting" where the actors act as if they know they are 10/10 actors. Instead of actually practicing to become a 10/10 actor. Writing was atrocious. Things were glossed over and forgotten about. The script was so cringe. Definitely not worth it's budget. I'm so tired of netflix canceling good shows like a-typical and then making horrible movies like this and the kissing booth series. You'd be better off staring into space than watching this.

But Mark Waters' 'He's All That' is a perfectly serviceable Netflix rom-com that fits the needs of the film. Addison Rae gives a competent performance, but she falls short of her more experienced costars and contemporaries.
Not impressed, this remake will never compare to the 1999 version. Really got you wondering if Hollywood has officially run out of ideas for new movies always messing with the classics nowadays smh.

reviews.review_title: I can not describe how bad this movie is .
reviews.content: The character's , the plot and the movie is just terrible. How they act in this movie is just bad, I don't even call this acting in my opinion.

A high school influencer trying to make a boy popular. She's annoying, her friends are annoying, the high schoolers are annoying. Rachel Leigh Cook doesn't even play Laney like in the original. This is Nickelodeon bad. I couldn't get through 20 minutes of it before I had to just stop it.

reviews.review_title: Its just a class project joke

Obviously a lot of cringe, some scenes the camera angles were off, acting wasn't the worst I've ever seen but not good by any means. The inclusion of some obvious individuals were pointless and served no purpose And the one thing probably worse than the acting was the product advertising/placement, it was consistent all throughout. reviews.review_title: Not a zero flick.. But a real disgrace to the original.
reviews.content: I have no idea who this TikTok person is. But every single review mentioned her. And as someone who didn't know her? She's a horrible horrible actress. But beyond that? We really have a very shallow character that actually works hard to try and make her likable.. Or a real relatable person and succeeds at neither.I actually watched it for Tanner Buchanan who I really liked on "Cobra Kai". He's not a great actor either. But definitely better than this.I am not even a huge fan of the original. But the plot worried at least even though I still find the slam poetry scene cringy as hell. Unfortunately this film basically starts with that and never isn't cringy. Packed full of advertisments for everything under the sun.It's not even a bad idea over all.. but the other characters are just so dumb and even the progression is awful. It just stickers around. The main character should be shallow and even a bit unlikable but the film goes to lengths to make her like super awesome. Which is wrong and she can't pull it off anyway. They should have made her warm up and it never works.The one bright spot for me was the original cast members. It's just a brief appearance but still more acting than anyone else in this "production" put in.A real shame because the original wasn't spectacularly original but had such sweet and even genuine performances from actors who seemed like real people. Unfortunately none of the teen cast in this can make that claim.
Addison Rae could not sing or act to save her life. What is this?!

reviews.review_title: A giant commercial for products with a She's All That skin

It's like a cheap, shallow version of the original.It's not the worst movie but it's so superficial.It's kinda like whet a lot of these movies for teens or tweens are like today,

reviews.review_title: If you liked the original do not watch.
reviews.content: My plan wasn't to watch it because I loved the original but my kids are obsessed with tiktok and by extension Addison Rae.Obviously in the day and age of the social media influencers and tiktok era it had to be about a girl losing followers!Follows the same basic plot, the other half of the couple cheats, the 'victim' bets with her friends they can turn anyone into a prom winner, befriends them and then falls for them, get found out then come back together in the end.Rachel Leigh Cook from the original plus Addison's mother, so I thought "oh Maybe she's playing a grown up version of Lainie Boggs from the original but no.And not even she or other original cast member Matthew Lillard can save this.In MY option this is actual recycled trash, I don't hate the actors, I just didn't like the film!
This movie could have been so gooodd....the script, the acting, everything a just didnt work! I cringed throughout this movie....will never watch again!

Next year, she is superseded by her imitators and forgotten, unable to "influence" her way to any more deals. "Such a pretty girl, what happened to her?" "She starred in that awful remake of She's All That."Awful indeed. A painful exercise in plodding, predictable, lazy filmmaking. "He's All That" is all paychecks and product placement, including the product known as Kourtney Kardashian whose shelf-life sell-by-date is rapidly approaching.And "Whatever happened to Rachael Leigh Cook?" "She had a bit part in that awful remake of She's All That."Tiktok tick tock, Addison. Time is running out. Paris Hilton and Lindsay Lohan are calling...

The ending was the only good part, I enjoyed Matthew Lillard and the runner up prom queen but otherwise, movie was trash. Rachael leigh cook and Matthew Lillard deserved better.

Instead of the protagonist being played by some promising and seasoned actress, Addison Rae is playing here. Since TikTok to forgive the "stars" have greater privileges to be in the lead roles than real actors who know the knowledge. Smart enough.

reviews.review_title: I wish there was a rating below 1
reviews.content: Terrible acting, bad plot, and way too much product placement. To say that this movie is a cash grab would be an understatement, but then again I can't imagine anyone paying actual money to watch this and actually enjoy it.

Of course it's not breaking new ground and its not doing anything original - but it doesn't need to - we know what's happening, what's gonna happen, and how it's going to end.I thought it was a really good gender swap. Absolutely adorable and perfectly entertaining.If you like this kind of movie and are capable looking past the original then there's lots to love here. reviews.review_title: Stop giving movie roles to people famous for lip-syncing

The ending was cute and classic rom com teen movie but the whole movie is bland. But not terrible. It's worth a watch. One time.
Utter cringeworthy s*hite!!! So bad I couldn't help but watch it, much like you can't help but look at a car crash.

I was surprised that so many people think Addison Rae can't act. I thought she did as good of a job as any of the other actors. Maybe people are jealous. Immature audience?I personally liked it enough to watch it in one sitting. It was entertaining.

This film is by far the worst thing I've ever seen. Don't waste your time.The acting? There wasn't any. The plot? Equally lacking. The throw backs to the original felt forced and like a slap in the face to what was a good 90s romcom by being included.

No one asked for a She's All That remake but here we are.bombarded with advertisements and OBVIOUS product placement within the first 3 minutesthe set and costume are absolutely horrible. KC Undercover was a children's show and still dressed Zendaya like a teen, not a childthe script...oh god it's awful. Everyone is just delivering lines and not acting except for Maddison Pettis and Tanner BuchananKourtney Kardashian? Really?All in all, don't watch this movie and just watch the original please.

I feel like everyone really needs to lighten up and stop being such angry critics. If you're going into this expecting an Oscar winning film then that is your mistake right there. It's a fluff move just meant to make you smile. I thought it was adorable. None of these types of movies have the best or deepest acting skills but it was entertaining and really nicely updated to fit today's social media world. I'm a huge fan of the original and I was anticipating really hating this remake but I have to be honest I totally loved it. Good job on the story! Hollywood is trying to bring these influencers to the acting industry and it's just not working. The real actors in this film did amazing but it's hard to really bring the film to light when the main character has no experience acting.

Madison Beer]" in the end credits was the only good thing about this movie, therefore the two stars.

That's the only good thing I can say about this new Netflix movie. Which pretty much says it all. Why don't these streaming services just stick to buying movies and TV shows that already exist? That's all we ask of them. I liked the little nods at the original movie, and returning cast. As well as some of the new one. And see locations that were used in things I grew up watching. But it wasn't necessary. One thing it did right though, was making me want to rewatch the OG version.

reviews.review_title: Absolutely awful! DISGRACE to the original
reviews.content: Seriously the best part of this movie was Matthew Lillard! The acting was so hard to watch. It's so sad. The soundtrack sounds like it was taken from all the songs on 2020 tiktok they only original song they kept from the original was kiss me and they still managed to ruin that absolute work of art. reviews.review_title: A rehash of the original, but with phones.
reviews.content: I was 21 when the original She's All That Came out. It's a film I've always loved. Sure, it's predictable and silly but at the heart of it is a good message and it's very sweet and funny.He's all that just feels like a cynical cash-in of the original. The plot is pretty much exactly the same, except of course being 2021 it features social media and people on their phones all the time.It isn't to say the film is totally without merit. The ending, though totally predictable, is kind of sweet, with a good message, but the whole film just feels so unnecessary. We all know Hollywood exists these days for sequels, remakes and reboots!Rachel Leigh Cook and Matthew Lillard from the original She's All That do appear in this movie and their roles are kind of fun and take a little look back at the original. Rachel Leigh Cook could almost be playing a 40 something Laney Boggs in this!I don't know, maybe it's age and rose tinted glasses, but He's All That just doesn't have the feel good factor of She's All That. I know, I know, I'm 43 now so the film isn't really aimed at my age group, but as I loved the original so much I had to see this Netflix effort. I think had I not known the original this movie would have seemed like an OK typical high school movie about popularity and the boy getting the girl etc.It's alright. But to be honest if you want to watch a "makeover movie" watch the 1999 original. Yes it's old and dated now, but it's far superior and sweeter.

reviews.review_title: Was doomed before it even started with Addison as the lead role
reviews.content: I don't even know where to start. Well, Addison as your lead role was already a complete failure of a movie even though she wasn't the worst thing of this movie, although that would be just about everything in it. I really thought Alden was gonna be a nice friend but they instead made her the bad guy which was horrifying and kind of poetic in the worst way possible . Don't even get me started on the terrible pacing and dialogue of this movie. Right after something happened it jumped right into another scene. People were talking 24/7, and I get its a movie, but the amount of dialogue is ridiculous. If your going to include tons of talking at least make it good writing and interactions. The acting was subpar at best and the plot of a girl betting on a guy to "transform him" feels like it's been reused so many times it's tiring. Matthew Lillard was easily the best part of this movie and he only had like 15 minutes of screen time. Quinn and Padgett's mom were the only other somewhat tolerable character's in this movie. Don't even get me started in that horrific what, 2 minute dance-off between the "bad" and "good" guys. There's also no one in their right mind who would forgive someone who only had romantic interest in them because of a bet in less than a day and act like nothing ever happened. Also riding in on a horse on school grounds doesn't seem like something that could happen . . . Ever. Not even in a damn movie if you want said movie to be good and not be considered a joke. Even the great Tanner Buchanan from Cobra Kai couldn't elevate this movie in any way, shape or form. The writing was just too awful and unbearable to work from the get go. This movie is so bad that it's funny, and that's the only reason I gave it 2 instead of 1/10 stars. Oh, and Addison, please just stick to your TikTok dances, it's whats in your best interests.

The guy playing the popstar was just....... No ? Tanner Buchanana has no acting range and was monotone and emotionless the whole time. Madison Pettis.... what was she doing here ? She needs to get booked for real movies ASAP. Isabella Cramp was probably the best actress (and a great one) in that movie. She's only 16 but I think she can go far into acting. 2021
12A
director: Mark Waters
starring: Addison Rae, Tanner Buchanan, Madison Pettis, Rachel Leigh Cook, Mathew Lillard, Peyton Meyer, Isabella Crovetti, Annie Jacob, Myra Molloy etcA teenage girl sets out to give a nebbish classmate the ultimate high school makeover. An updated remake of the 1999 film, She's All That. This film really wasn't that bad at all, people are being way too harsh. I think certain people who review it need to realise the target audience for the film.My first few positives would be the performances, likeable characters, and humour. As well as the chemistry between the cast and the fun cameo. The performances in this film were pretty good. Tanner Buchanan did a great job here, his performance was charming and the character he portrayed was relatable and funny and he stole the show. And I have to say Addison Rae did a good job here. She has got unnecessary hate. For her first big acting role she showed a lot of charm and promise, there are obviously a few things to work on, but respect to her for doing a solid job. The film was also funny, at least in my case it was occasionally for the wrong reasons. But the film was funny due to its extreme self-awareness, and the chemistry between the cast members. There were also some pretty funny lines from Tanner's character. The cast also had fantastic chemistry here. Addison and Tanner had great chemistry with each other. They worked together well, and their romance was sweet and charming as they grew as characters. I also liked the chemistry between Addison and Rachel Cook, their mother and daughter relationship was sweet. The cameo from Kourtney Kardashian was also funny as well, it was very cringy, but I found it entertaining that she used a different name for the film.My first few negatives would be the script and dialogue. As well as how generic and predictable the film is. Also, the odd main concept. The script was extremely poorly written, adding absolutely nothing new to genre and following every genre trope you can think of it was very generic, formulaic, and safe which is fine as long as you know what to expect. The film was also painfully predictable. You could tell how the film was going to play out and predict the different plot points before they even happened, it's a shame as they could have tried something a little out of the box. But once again this was expected, but it was still poorly handled. The Dialogue was also extremely corny and eye rolling. There were certain lines that have been used in countless other teen rom coms and it made me want to vomit slightly in parts. I also found the main concept strange. Tanner was already attractive before he had his makeover for the film, all they did was cut his hair and make him dress smarter. However, the bare minimum was done in the original film as well.My next few positives would be the decent set up for the main plot point, as well as the great set locations and character development. As well as the charming tone and fun scenes. I thought the set up for Padgett and Cameron meeting was a decent way to set up the main plot point of the bet for prom king and to have Padgett develop as a character. I thought the film had great set locations. The films sets were beautiful and set the mood for some fun scenes with the different events and parties and it helped with the films visual appeal. The film had decent character development. Padgett really grew as a character as her relationship with Cameron grew. She became a lot less self-obsessed and a lot more thoughtful and started living her life as herself instead of a fake personality for social media. And Cameron really grew and came out of his shell, Padgett made him be himself more. And the development about his family and his mum was sweet and gave him some decent character depth. I also thought the film had a harmless and fun charming tone, it didn't take itself too seriously, it knew what kind of movie it was, and the cast had good chemistry, so I found it very charming a lot of the time. There were some fun and entertaining scenes with the different parties that despite being very cheesy were sweet and fun to watch.My final few negatives would be the corny set up, lack of character background and unlikeable character decisions. The whole set up with Padgett losing her followers and popularity was extremely corny and just lazily set up. The set up for her redemption was good enough but this was poor. I also thought there was a lack of character depth and background to most of the characters. The supporting cast was likeable, but they were all very one dimensional and didn't deliver too much to the story. I also thought there was some unlikeable character decisions. It just felt a bit strange that Padgett was still going with the bet with Cameron for so long even when she grew feelings for him. I get the needed conflict, but it was oddly structured for me, and it made her character unlikeable for parts of the film.My final few positives would be the villains, good LGBT representation. As well as the fun final act, good themes, and uplifting ending. I thought the film did a good job with its villains. Both villains were very unlikeable and did their roles well. And when they eventually got what they deserved it was satisfying. I also liked the good LGBT representation. The film didn't shy away from having LGBT supporting characters which is great to see, Annie Jacob and Myra Molloy actually got their own storyline in the film, and it was a nice little bit of representation. The final act was also fun. It was entertaining and completely harmless. I was smiling so it did its job at having solid character arcs and good themes on accepting yourself, and not being fake on social media. The ending was also uplifting, due to being party invested in the main characters relationship them getting together was satisfying and very corny but it was a good cheesy ending.Overall, He's all that is far from a masterpiece. But nowhere near as bad as what people are saying. Despite being painfully predictable and generic, and adding nothing new to the genre. It is surprisingly watchable. Due to the films charm, chemistry between the leads and its self-awareness. I watched the film knowing exactly what it was going to be and who its target audience was, so I enjoyed it a lot more.Overall score 58/100.

If I directed this I would be horrified at what I had created. Netflix sort it out please.

reviews.review_title: this popped up after watching something on Netflix!
reviews.content: And I went for it! Lol, but then when I saw Rachel Leigh I was like oh, wait, he's all that, then I remembered she was in She's all that! And although the first one didn't agree with me too well , so I guess I had terrible misgivings about moving forward with this one I stayed with it anyway and gave it a chance and I'm so glad I did! This is the writing I wanted for the first one! It was sweet and witty and funny and clever and smart and brilliant and thoughtful and sincere and above all honest and it made for a fun barn burner! I really do feel this way! I loved it! And I think everyone did a great job , who knows perhaps this handsome lead might be the next Batman or something, lots of great up and coming talent but for me, the writing on this one was superlative, not a single complaint something didn't flow right or something terrible jarring and disgusting (meaning something that tramps all over the incipient stages of it's own writing) there was none of that, it built on itself , it worked through the characters, it handled the whole modern content very well which is not easy owing to all of the extra intel flying all around , it seems like the world is hauling major ass sitting on top of a major wave dashing against all sorts of different ways of distracting ourselves , and this captured this zeitgeist and ran with and made something I believe to be truly special! Great job. I really want to see another one of these! I really do! How about They're all that, but all Asian people or something, throw in a dragon! Who knows! This was very cool though!

It's one thing to do a remake - but at least TRY to make it unique or well executed.First and foremost, hire actual actors, not someone from Tiktok as your lead.Second, understand the source material. The same guy who wrote the original wrote this one, and I'm assuming he knows Pygmalion. Why did this one crash and burn?Third, if retelling Pygmalion, focus on the Eliza Doolittle character, not the Professor Higgins. Especially if the girl you have in the Higgins role CAN'T ACT!Finally, people defending this film...hey, I like trashy films, too. We all have our guilty pleasures.This film received so few stars because it's a remake that crashed and burned by putting someone in the lead who can't act.If they'd had an actual actress in the role, it could have been a 5/10.
